question: How fast is electric vehicle adoption growing in Ontario?
answer: Caches 16 quarterly CSVs of EV registrations by Forward Sortation Area. Runs province-wide totals with window functions.
punchline: Ontario's registered EVs surged from 37,595 in Q1 2022 to 246,448 by Q4 2025 — a 6.6× increase in under four years, with battery-electric vehicles making up about three-quarters of the fleet.

sources.title: Electric Vehicles in Ontario -- By Forward Sortation Area

hood.sql:
SELECT quarter,
  SUM(TRY_CAST("Total EV" AS INTEGER)) AS total_evs,
  ROUND(SUM(TRY_CAST("Total EV" AS INTEGER)) * 1.0 /
    LAG(SUM(TRY_CAST("Total EV" AS INTEGER))) OVER (
      ORDER BY quarter
    ), 2) AS growth
FROM ev_registrations
GROUP BY quarter
ORDER BY quarter

followup.question: Which postal codes saw the fastest EV growth?
followup.answer: Your 16 quarterly CSVs are already cached. Compares Q1 2022 to Q4 2025 per FSA.
followup.punchline: BEVs consistently make up 72–75% of all EVs. Growth accelerated in 2025: Q4 2025 (246,448) is more than double Q4 2024 (119,846).

sources.title: Electric Vehicles in Ontario -- By Forward Sortation Area

question: How much slower are Ontario ambulances compared to three years ago?
answer: Downloads ambulance response time CSVs for 50+ coverage areas. Compares 2020 vs 2023 average response times by region.
punchline: Response times jumped 1–2 minutes province-wide between 2020 and 2023. Kenora waits nearly 15 minutes (14:56) — almost 2 minutes longer than 2020. Even urban Durham went from 6:38 to 8:10.

sources.title: Land Ambulance Response Time Standard - Response Times

hood.sql:
SELECT "Ambulance Service Coverage Area",
  old."Average Response Time" AS resp_2020,
  new."Average Response Time" AS resp_2023
FROM ambulance_2023 new
JOIN ambulance_2020 old
  ON new."Ambulance Service Coverage Area"
   = old."Ambulance Service Coverage Area"
ORDER BY new."Average Response Time" DESC

followup.question: Does population density predict ambulance wait times?
followup.answer: Re-uses cached data, joins population density. Areas under 5 people/km² average 13–15 min; areas over 100/km² average 7–8 min.
followup.punchline: The gap between fastest (Weeneebayko, 6:18) and slowest (Kenora, 14:56) is 8 minutes and 38 seconds.

sources.title: Land Ambulance Response Time Standard - Response Times

question: Which Ontario facilities had the most air emission violations in 2024?
answer: Downloads 2024 air emissions compliance data — 279 records across 44 facilities. Groups by facility owner using SUM on the exceedance count column.
punchline: Three steel companies — Algoma Steel (408), ArcelorMittal Dofasco (385), and Stelco (307) — accounted for 1,100 of Ontario's 1,639 reported exceedances. Opacity (visible smoke) alone was 84% of all violations.

hood.sql:
SELECT "Facility Owner",
  SUM(TRY_CAST("No. of Exceedances" AS INTEGER)) AS total
FROM air_emissions_2024
GROUP BY "Facility Owner"
ORDER BY total DESC
LIMIT 10

followup.question: What contaminants are driving the violations?
followup.answer: Groups the same 279 records by contaminant type.
followup.punchline: Opacity alone accounts for 1,375 of 1,639 total exceedances (84%). The Iron and Steel sector generated 1,261 — more than all other industries combined.

question: How has phosphorus in Ontario's Great Lakes changed since the 1970s?
answer: Caches 439,841 water quality readings from drinking water intakes (1976–2023). Averages total phosphorus by lake and decade.
punchline: Lake Ontario saw the steepest decline — from 0.021 mg/L in the late 1970s to 0.010 mg/L by the 2010s, a 54% drop. Lake Erie fell 29% but remains more than double the concentration of Huron or Superior.

sources.title: Lake Water Quality at Drinking Water Intakes

hood.sql:
SELECT "LAKE",
  FLOOR("YEAR" / 10) * 10 AS decade,
  ROUND(AVG(TRY_CAST("RESULT_VALUE" AS DOUBLE)), 4)
    AS avg_phosphorus_mg_L,
  COUNT(*) AS n_readings
FROM lake_water_quality
WHERE "PARAMETER" LIKE '%Phosphorus%total%'
GROUP BY "LAKE", decade
ORDER BY "LAKE", decade

followup.question: Is phosphorus in Lake Erie getting better or worse?
followup.answer: Filters to Lake Erie from the same cached 439k readings. Averages by decade.
followup.punchline: Lake Erie phosphorus dropped from 0.032 mg/L (1976–1989) to 0.024 (1990s), rebounded to 0.029 in the 2000s, then settled at 0.024 by 2010–2019. Still the most nutrient-rich Great Lake.

sources.title: Lake Water Quality at Drinking Water Intakes

question: Where are Ontario's 6,000+ licensed child care centres?
answer: Downloads the Dec 2025 XLSX snapshot of all licensed facilities. Groups active centres by city and region.
punchline: Ontario has 6,235 active licensed child care facilities across 750 cities. Toronto alone accounts for 972 — nearly 1 in 6. The YMCA of Greater Toronto operates 307 sites, making it the largest single operator.

sources.title: Licensed child care facilities in Ontario

hood.sql:
SELECT City,
  COUNT(*) AS active_facilities
FROM child_care
WHERE "Licence Status" = 'Active'
GROUP BY City
ORDER BY active_facilities DESC
LIMIT 10

followup.question: Which regions are adding the most new facilities?
followup.answer: Filters by Original Issue Date since January 2024. Groups new licenses by region.
followup.punchline: 512 new facilities licensed since Jan 2024. Southwest Ontario and West Region each added over 100 new facilities, outpacing Toronto's 34.

sources.title: Licensed child care facilities in Ontario

question: How fast is autism-related special education enrolment growing in Ontario?
answer: Downloads 3 years of province-wide special education data (pipe-delimited TXT). Compares enrolment by exceptionality across 2021–22, 2023–24, and 2024–25.
punchline: Autism enrolment surged from 27,095 to 35,335 students in three years — a 30.4% increase. It now accounts for 9.7% of all 362,620 special education students, up from 7.7%.

hood.sql:
SELECT "Academic Year",
  "Area of Exceptionality",
  TRY_CAST("Total Special Education Enrolment"
    AS INTEGER) AS total
FROM special_education
WHERE "Area of Exceptionality" = 'Autism'
ORDER BY "Academic Year"

followup.question: What's the largest special education category overall?
followup.answer: Uses the same 3-year cached data. Ranks all exceptionalities by total enrolment for 2024–25.
followup.punchline: Learning Disability is the largest formally identified category at 50,155 students. But 'Non-Identified' dwarfs everything at 190,720 — 52.6% of all special education enrolment.
